G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this case under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as it is a civil action in which the damages exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions giving rise to the events in question occurred in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, within the jurisdiction of the Berkshire Division of the Superior Court.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 930 N.E.2d 142 (2010)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to persons lawfully on or near their property to prevent harm caused by unsafe conditions known to the owner.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, and it applies that duty to hazards from snow and ice once the natural/unnatural distinction is abolished. This aligns with the proposition that owners must exercise reasonable care to prevent harm from unsafe conditions they know or should know about on or near their property. The case is thus properly cited as authority for that general duty rule.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property … the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28,.raw_text: Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28, 247 N.E.2d 333 (1969)
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to persons lawfully on or near their property to prevent harm caused by unsafe conditions known to the owner.
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28,.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt focuses on contributory negligence and assumption of risk, not on defining the underlying duty of care owed by a property owner. The court does not analyze or articulate the scope of any landowner’s duty to persons on or near the property; it simply assumes some potential liability and holds that whether plaintiff was contributorily negligent or assumed the risk is for the jury. Thus, it does not serve as authority for the stated Massachusetts duty-of-care proposition.
Halley v. Hugh Nawn, Inc., 356 Mass. 28,.relevant_excerpt:
“The issues argued by Hugh Nawn, Incorporated and New England Telephone and Telegraph Company are that the injured plaintiff assumed the risk and was contributorily negligent in that she left ‘a place of safety’ and ‘voluntarily exposed herself to a danger which she . . . had to appreciate.’

Under G. L. c. 231, § 85, the defendants had the burden of proving contributory negligence. They also had the burden of proving that the plaintiff assumed the risk.… The questions of contributory negligence and assumption of the risk were for the jury to determine.”

Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37.raw_text: Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37 Mass. App. Ct. 642, 642 N.E.2d 279 (1994)
Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37.proposition: A reasonably prudent person in Defendant’s position would have acted to remove, trim, or inspect the tree branch after being notified of its condition.
Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37.case_name: K. Hovnanian at Taunton, Inc. v. City of Taunton
Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns sewer connection rights, intermunicipal agreements, and civil rights claims; it does not involve trees, branches, premises liability, or the standard of care for a landowner after notice of a hazardous condition. There is no discussion of what a reasonably prudent person would do regarding removal, trimming, or inspection of a tree branch. Thus, the case does not support the stated negligence/proprietor-duty proposition and appears to be an inapposite citation.
Gleason v. Hillcrest Builders, Inc., 37.relevant_excerpt: “Central to proof of a violation of G. L. c. 12, § 11I, is the existence of a right secured by ‘the Constitution or laws of either the United States or of the Commonwealth.’ … At trial, however, Hovnanian focused its claims not upon an interference with any general right to use of its property, but upon the deprivation by the defendants of its claimed right to tie into the South Walker Street line and to the approval of its subdivision plan… That narrow focus fails to implicate any remedy provided under G. L. c. 12, § 11I.”

Souza v. Southworth, 326 Mass. 121, 93 N.proposition: A reasonably prudent person in Defendant’s position would have acted to remove, trim, or inspect the tree branch after being notified of its condition.
Souza v. Southworth, 326 Mass. 121, 93 N.case_name: Bureau of Old Age Assistance v. Commissioner of Public Welfare
Souza v. Southworth, 326 Mass. 121, 93 N.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the authority of a state welfare department to impose financial obligations on municipalities via regulation and the statutory allocation of responsibility for old age assistance. It does not involve negligence, trees, property maintenance, or the conduct of a reasonably prudent person after notice of a dangerous condition. Therefore it provides no support for the asserted proposition about what a reasonably prudent person would have done regarding a tree branch.
Souza v. Southworth, 326 Mass. 121, 93 N.relevant_excerpt: There is nothing in any of the matters specifically mentioned as being subject to rules and regulations of the department that permits the imposition of an obligation upon a town to furnish old age assistance to one who never had a settlement in the town after he no longer resides in the town but has voluntarily taken up his residence in another city or town.

Gill v. Usher, 327 Mass. 641, 100 N.E.2d.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act when he knew or reasonably should have known of the hazardous condition constituted negligence.
Gill v. Usher, 327 Mass. 641, 100 N.E.2d.support_reasoning: This case is a criminal appeal involving murder and robbery, focused on evidentiary rulings, jury selection, and sufficiency of the evidence, not on negligence or a defendant’s duty to act regarding a hazardous condition. Nowhere does the opinion discuss standards of reasonable care, premises liability, or failure to remedy or warn of a hazard. Accordingly, it does not establish or affirm the negligence principle described in the proposition.
Gill v. Usher, 327 Mass. 641, 100 N.E.2d.relevant_excerpt: Assignment 38, filed at the conclusion of the Commonwealth’s case, is to the denial of a motion for a directed verdict in each case. There was no error. From the evidence introduced by the Commonwealth the jury could have found that the body found in the closet was that of Mrs. Burnett; that she had been murdered; and that the defendant had committed the murder on June 29. The jury could also have found that the defendant stole the radio from her by the use of force and was guilty of robbery.

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act when he knew or reasonably should have known of the hazardous condition constituted negligence.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that both the trustees and the elevator company could be found negligent based on their failure to inspect and maintain the elevator when defects were or should have been known. The court emphasizes that the governor’s condition and the loose/inoperative interlocks were either known or readily discoverable upon proper inspection, and that the elevator company had a contractual duty to maintain the elevator in a safe condition. This aligns with the proposition that failing to act when one knows or reasonably should know of a hazardous condition constitutes negligence.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.relevant_excerpt:
There was evidence from which the jury could infer that the elevator company had not cleaned the governor for more than ten years prior to the accident; that the congealed grease and accumulated dirt in the governor were readily observable upon inspection; that this condition had existed for at least six months prior to the accident; that Bay State was aware of the faulty condition of the interlocks; that the interlock which fell into the pit had been loose for some time prior to the accident; and that this defect too was discoverable upon proper inspection.
...
Most or all of the defects were either known to them or discoverable upon inquiry.

Donahue v. Irving, 335 Mass. 394, 140 N..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Donahue v. Irving, 335 Mass. 394, 140 N..support_reasoning: The opinion is an equity case about ownership of a joint savings account and an insurance policy between a father and son. It does not involve negligence, causation, or personal injuries at all, and therefore cannot support the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The citation would be inapposite for that proposition.
Donahue v. Irving, 335 Mass. 394, 140 N..relevant_excerpt: This is suit in equity arising out of a controversy between a father and son as to their respective rights in an insurance policy on the life of the father, in which no beneficiary is designated, and in an account in a Salem savings bank standing in the names of the father and son jointly, payable to either or the survivor.

MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.raw_text: MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131, 475 N.E.2d 65 (1985)
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses causation and explicitly notes that the jury found the inadequacy of Ortho’s warning to be the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injury, and the Supreme Judicial Court reinstates that verdict. Although the opinion’s main doctrinal focus is on duty to warn, the court expressly recognizes and leaves intact the jury’s proximate cause finding as supported by the evidence. Thus, it is proper authority for the proposition that the defendant’s negligence (failure to warn) was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.relevant_excerpt: "The jury also found that Ortho was negligent and in breach of warranty because it failed to give MacDonald sufficient warning of such dangers. The jury further found that MacDonald’s injury was caused by Ortho’s pills, that the inadequacy of the warnings to MacDonald was the proximate cause of her injury, and that Ortho was liable to MacDonald and her husband."
